Authors: Tran, N.-H.T.; Oguchi, T.; Matsunaga, E.; Kawaoka, A.; Watanabe, K.N.; Kikuchi, A.
Author full names: Tran, Ngoc Ha Thi (57204200026); Oguchi, Taichi (23992587700); Matsunaga, Etsuko (7005750324); Kawaoka, Akiyoshi (6602987726); Watanabe, Kazuo N. (57194224442); Kikuchi, Akira (56088217100)
Title: Evaluation of potential impacts on biodiversity of the salt-tolerant transgenic Eucalyptus camaldulensis harboring an RNA chaperonic RNA-Binding-Protein gene derived from common ice plant
Affiliations: Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Gene Research Center, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Faculty of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Agri-Biotechnology Research Laboratory, Nippon Paper Industries Co., Ltd, Tokyo, Japan; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Tropical Biology, Dalat, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Ngoc Ha Thi, Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Tropical Biology, Dalat, Viet Nam; Oguchi, Taichi, Gene Research Center, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan, Faculty of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Matsunaga, Etsuko, Agri-Biotechnology Research Laboratory, Nippon Paper Industries Co., Ltd, Tokyo, Japan; Kawaoka, Akiyoshi, Agri-Biotechnology Research Laboratory, Nippon Paper Industries Co., Ltd, Tokyo, Japan; Watanabe, Kazuo N., Gene Research Center, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan, Faculty of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Kikuchi, Akira, Gene Research Center, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan, Faculty of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: We recently reported that a genetic transformation of the RNA-Binding-Protein (McRBP), an RNA chaperone gene derived from common ice plant (Mesembryanthemum crystallinum), alleviated injury and loss of biomass production by salt stress in Eucalyptus camaldulensis in a semi-confined screen house trial. In this study, we assessed the potential environmental impact of the transgenic Eucalyptus in a manner complying with Japanese biosafety regulatory framework required for getting permission for experimental confined field trials. Two kinds of bioassays for the effects of allelopathic activity on the growth of other plants, i.e., the sandwich assay and the succeeding crop assay, were performed for three transgenic lines and three non-transgenic lines. No significant differences were observed between transgenic and non-transgenic plants. No significant difference in the numbers of cultivable microorganisms analyzed by the spread plate method were observed among the six transgenic and non-transgenic lines. These results suggested that there is no significant difference in the potential impact on biodiversity between the transgenic McRBP-E. camaldulensis lines and their non-transgenic comparators. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Biosafety; Environmental risk assessment (ERA); Mesembryanthemum crystallinum; RNA-binding protein; Transgenic trees

Authors: Bahari, M.B.; Setiabudi, H.D.; Nishino, T.; Ayas, N.; Vo, D.-V.N.
Author full names: Bahari, Mahadi B. (57189077303); Setiabudi, Herma Dina (51864605900); Nishino, Tomomichi (57219287231); Ayas, Nezihe (56123939200); Vo, Dai Viet N. (35957358000)
Title: Coke-resistant Y2O3-promoted cobalt supported on mesoporous alumina for enhanced hydrogen production
Affiliations: Faculty of Chemical and Process Engineering Technology, Universiti Malaysia Pahang Al-Sultan Abdullah, Pekan, Malaysia; Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Akita College, Akita, Japan; Department of Chemical Engineering, Eskisehir Technical University, Eskisehir, Turkey; Center of Excellence for Green Energy and Environmental Nanomaterials (CE@GrEEN), Dại học Nguyen Tat Thanh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Bahari, Mahadi B., Faculty of Chemical and Process Engineering Technology, Universiti Malaysia Pahang Al-Sultan Abdullah, Pekan, Malaysia; Setiabudi, Herma Dina, Faculty of Chemical and Process Engineering Technology, Universiti Malaysia Pahang Al-Sultan Abdullah, Pekan, Malaysia; Nishino, Tomomichi, Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Akita College, Akita, Japan; Ayas, Nezihe, Department of Chemical Engineering, Eskisehir Technical University, Eskisehir, Turkey; Vo, Dai Viet N., Center of Excellence for Green Energy and Environmental Nanomaterials (CE@GrEEN), Dại học Nguyen Tat Thanh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: In this work, the δ%Y–10%Co/MA (δ = 0, 1, 2, 3, and 5 wt%) catalysts synthesised by sequential incipient wetness impregnation were characterised and evaluated in CH<inf>4</inf> dry reforming. Superior catalytic performances were shown by 3 wt% Y<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> loading (CH<inf>4</inf> conversion = 85.8%, and CO<inf>2</inf> conversion = 90.5%), followed by 2 wt% > 5 wt% > 1 wt% > 0 wt% Y<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> loading. This result was attributed to the favorable catalytic properties of 3 wt%Y–10%Co/MA including small Co particle size, high Co dispersion, high amount of atomic ratio (Co/Al), and high number of lattice oxygen vacancies. The excess Y<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> addition (>3 wt%) led to inevitably blocked Co active sites and resulted in decreasing catalytic performance. The 3 wt% Y<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> promoter loading recorded the lowest carbon deposited (7.0%) due to the highest oxygen vacancies (78.1%) compared to 1, 2 and 5 wt% Y<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: CH4 dry reforming; Cobalt-based catalyst; Mesoporous alumina; Syngas; Y2O3 promoter
Index Keywords: Alumina; Aluminum oxide; Hydrogen production; Oxygen vacancies; Particle size; Atomic ratio; Catalytic performance; Catalytic properties; Dry reforming; Enhanced hydrogen productions; Incipientwetness impregnation; Lattice oxygen vacancies; Mesoporous alumina; Cobalt

Authors: Hashimoto, T.; Takai, K.; Nguyen, H.V.Q.; Nomura, M.; Ishihara, A.
Author full names: Hashimoto, Tadanori (35431009300); Takai, Kentarou (57217034311); Nguyen, Hung Viet Quang (57221674969); Nomura, Masakatsu (35551407600); Ishihara, Atsushi (7202191250)
Title: Analysis of Thermal Behavior of Crystalline Minerals in Bituminous Coal Samples under Air and Argon Atmospheres
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry for Materials, Mie University, Tsu, Japan; Center of Severe Materials and Environment, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Applied Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hashimoto, Tadanori, Department of Chemistry for Materials, Mie University, Tsu, Japan; Takai, Kentarou, Department of Chemistry for Materials, Mie University, Tsu, Japan; Nguyen, Hung Viet Quang, Department of Chemistry for Materials, Mie University, Tsu, Japan, Center of Severe Materials and Environment, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nomura, Masakatsu, Department of Applied Chemistry, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Ishihara, Atsushi, Department of Chemistry for Materials, Mie University, Tsu, Japan
Abstract: The thermal behavior of ash components in two bituminous coal samples [Upper Freeport (the "UF") and Illinois #6 (the "IL")] was investigated under air and argon atmospheres in the temperature range of 800-1200 °C using thermal gravimetric-differential thermal analysis, X-ray diffraction transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and TEM-energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry measurements. The UF treated under air formed the needle-like crystals which were assumed to be mullite-related substances formed by transformation of andalusite, because the crystals are mainly composed of SiO2 and Al2O3. In contrast to the UF, the IL did not generate such crystals; however, when the IL was treated under air after carbonization under Ar, crystals appeared. The composition of the UF with an Al/Si ratio higher than that of the IL favored the formation of mullite-related substances, while the presence of lime in the IL inhibited the formation of mullite-related substances. Oldhamite was formed by the reaction of lime with sulfur at the carbonization of the IL under Ar and remained even at the successive air treatment. As lime was consumed, the formation of mullite-related substances was ceased to be inhibited under air after Ar treatment. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Ogawa, S.; Selvaraj, M.G.; Ishitani, M.
Author full names: Ogawa, Satoshi (56204920100); Selvaraj, Michael Gomez (55921854600); Ishitani, Manabu (7005085023)
Title: Crop Development with Data-driven Approach towards Sustainable Agriculture: Lifting the Achievements and Opportunities of Collaborative Research between CIAT and Japan
Affiliations: Livestock and Environment Division, Japan International Research Center for Agricultural Sciences, Tsukuba, Japan; Crops for Nutrition and Health, Centro Internacional de Agricultura Tropical, Cali, Colombia; Crops for Nutrition and Health, Bioversity International, Rome, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Ogawa, Satoshi, Livestock and Environment Division, Japan International Research Center for Agricultural Sciences, Tsukuba, Japan; Selvaraj, Michael Gomez, Crops for Nutrition and Health, Centro Internacional de Agricultura Tropical, Cali, Colombia; Ishitani, Manabu, Crops for Nutrition and Health, Centro Internacional de Agricultura Tropical, Cali, Colombia, Crops for Nutrition and Health, Bioversity International, Rome, Italy
Abstract: International Center for Tropical Agriculture (CIAT) has a long history of collaboration with Japanese institutions to develop improved crop varieties and adopt agricultural technologies with pioneering approaches for farmers’ benefit. Since 1972, Japan has enjoyed a long history of successful cooperation with the CGIAR (formerly the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research) after becoming its 22nd Member to meet global challenges such as climate change affecting agriculture and food systems in diplomacy through Japan’s advanced science and technology. This long-standing collaboration adopts agricultural technologies developed in Japan and promotes agricultural innovation through cutting-edge technologies such as remote sensing for Internet of Things (IoT) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) that will provide novel solutions to the agriculture and food sectors in the tropics. Nowadays, it is presumed that this approach to data-driven agriculture realization will help establish a sustainable agroecosystem with increased agricultural productivity and sustainability by adapting or mitigating the effects of climate change and efficient use of natural resources and establishing a sustainable food value chain. This review highlights the research collaborations and new opportunities on advanced breeding technologies and digital innovations towards data-driven agriculture. In conjunction, we present a potential collaborative research between CIAT and Japan, prioritizing the current and future challenges in agriculture and food systems © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Artificial intelligence (ai); Cassava; Genome editing; Marker-assisted breeding; Precision agriculture; Rice; Tropical forage

Authors: Le Dinh, C.; Fujiwara, T.; Pham Phu, S.T.P.
Author full names: Le Dinh, Cuong (57222016137); Fujiwara, Takeshi (55502389900); Pham Phu, Song Toan (57201079513)
Title: Waste Segregation at Source and Separately Collection - The Inadequacy in Implementation in Vietnam
Affiliations: Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; University of Science and Technology, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Le Dinh, Cuong, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Fujiwara, Takeshi, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Pham Phu, Song Toan, University of Science and Technology, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Abstract: Hoi An city is a dynamic tourism city in Vietnam which had received the certificate of World Heritage Site by UNESCO. The boom in tourism activities led to problems for the solid waste management system. Solid waste collection activities account for the largest proportion of expenses on solid waste management. Optimization of the present solid waste collection system of Hoi An city is an urgent mission. This research is an effort to describe the current solid waste collection system of Hoi An city with the support of GIS and GPS. The results denoted Thursday, Friday, and Saturday accounted for the most enormous workload with 36, 34, and 40 trips. The total working time for these days were 103.86, 96.12, and 109.6 h while the total traveled distances were 733.76, 719.21, and 848.12 km. The complexity of solid waste collection routes, frequencies of solid waste collection, and coverage of solid waste collection activities decreased from urban areas to rural areas. Collection of waste accounted for the largest amount of time in solid waste collection activities. The low rate of waste separation at source, illegal solid waste collection, extreme weather, misbehaviours of drivers and workers, as well as the limitation in waste treatment facilities were the problems and challenges of the solid waste collection system in Hoi An city. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Funding Texts: The authors are thankful to Hoi An Public Work Company for supporting the survey as well as Graduate School of Environmental and Life Science, Okayama University for financial support.

Authors: Nguyen, D.B.; Pham Phu, S.T.P.; Le Dinh, C.; Usami, M.
Author full names: Nguyen, Duy Bao (57406388400); Pham Phu, Song Toan (57201079513); Le Dinh, Cuong (57222016137); Usami, Makoto (57406996800)
Title: Practical Solid Waste Management System in a Campus in Danang city, Vietnam
Affiliations: Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; University of Science and Technology, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Graduate School of Global Environmental Studies, Kyoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duy Bao, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Pham Phu, Song Toan, University of Science and Technology, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Le Dinh, Cuong, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Usami, Makoto, Graduate School of Global Environmental Studies, Kyoto, Japan
Abstract: Da Nang is a city with rapid growth and expansion, along with it is pressure for municipal solid waste treatment. Within a decade, waste generation from commercial and service activities increased significantly at a rate of 9 %/y and reached 1.073 t/d in 2018. This study aims at developing municipal solid waste management toward sustainability in the campus of Danang University. A waste audit was performed to evaluate the total emission and characteristics of the solid waste generated by the campus. Simultaneously, the 3R program was applied for assessing the current status of the waste management practice (WMP) system. This study analyzes the total amount and characteristics of campus waste, in which, recycling (25 %) and organic waste (28 %) took up a great proportion. It also reveals that even though a big part has shown disinterest in waste management, the awareness of students toward environmental protection was raised during the process of this research. Therefore, the improvement of WMP at source and formal environmental education at a younger age can reduce a significant amount of waste-to-landfill, as well as enhancing environmental awareness. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Study on combining two faster r-cnn models for landslide detection with a classification decision tree to improve the detection performance
Affiliations: Sirindhorn International Institute of Technology Thammasat University, Khlong Luang, Thailand; Sirindhorn International Institute of Technology Thammasat University, Khlong Luang, Thailand; School of Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; National Institute of Information and Communications Technology, Koganei, Japan; Graduate School of Science and Technology, Gunma University, Maebashi, Japan; Graduate School of Information Science, Teikyo Heisei University, Ichihara, Japan; Geotechnical Engineering, Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thailand National Electronics and Computer Technology Center, Pathum Thani, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Tanatipuknon, Asadang, Sirindhorn International Institute of Technology Thammasat University, Khlong Luang, Thailand; Aimmanee, Pakinee, Sirindhorn International Institute of Technology Thammasat University, Khlong Luang, Thailand; Watanabe, Yoshihiro, School of Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Murata, Ken T., National Institute of Information and Communications Technology, Koganei, Japan; Wakai, Akihiko, Graduate School of Science and Technology, Gunma University, Maebashi, Japan; Sato, Go, Graduate School of Information Science, Teikyo Heisei University, Ichihara, Japan; Hung, Hoangviet, Geotechnical Engineering, Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tungpimolrut, Kanokvate, Thailand National Electronics and Computer Technology Center, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Keerativittayanun, Suthum, Thailand National Electronics and Computer Technology Center, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Karnjana, Jessada, Thailand National Electronics and Computer Technology Center, Pathum Thani, Thailand
Abstract: This study aims to improve the accuracy of landslide detection in satellite images by combining two object detection models based on a faster region-based convolutional neural network (Faster R-CNN) with a classification decision tree. The proposed method combines the predicted results from the two Faster R-CNN models and classifies their features with a classification decision tree to generate a bounding-box that surrounds the landslide area in the input image. The first Faster R-CNN model is trained by using a training set of color images (RGB images). The second model is trained by using grayscale images that represent digital elevation models (DEMs). The results from both models are used to construct features for training a classification decision tree. The resulting bounding-box is selected from the following four classes: the box obtained from the RGB model, the box obtained from the DEM model, the intersection of those two boxes, and the smallest box that contains the union of them. The evaluation results show that the proposed method is better than the RGB model in terms of accuracy, precision, recall, F-measure, and Intersectionover-Union (IoU) score. It is slightly better than the DEM model in almost all evaluation metrics, except the precision. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Classification decision tree; Faster R-CNN; Landslide detection; Satellite imagery

Title: A novel recursive non-parametric dbscan algorithm for 3d data analysis with an application in rockfall detection
Affiliations: Sirindhorn International Institute of Technology Thammasat University, Khlong Luang, Thailand; Thailand National Electronics and Computer Technology Center, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Graduate School of Science and Technology, Gunma University, Maebashi, Japan; Graduate School of Information Science, Teikyo Heisei University, Ichihara, Japan; Faculty of Civil Engineering, Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Sirindhorn International Institute of Technology Thammasat University, Khlong Luang, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Dillon, Pitisit, Sirindhorn International Institute of Technology Thammasat University, Khlong Luang, Thailand, Thailand National Electronics and Computer Technology Center, Pathum Thani, Thailand; Aimmanee, Pakinee, Sirindhorn International Institute of Technology Thammasat University, Khlong Luang, Thailand; Wakai, Akihiko, Graduate School of Science and Technology, Gunma University, Maebashi, Japan; Sato, Go, Graduate School of Information Science, Teikyo Heisei University, Ichihara, Japan; Hung, Hoangviet, Faculty of Civil Engineering, Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Karnjana, Jessada, Thailand National Electronics and Computer Technology Center, Pathum Thani, Thailand
Abstract: The density-based spatial clustering of applications with noise (DBSCAN) algorithm is a well-known algorithm for spatial-clustering data point clouds. It can be applied to many applications, such as crack detection, rockfall detection, and glacier movement detection. Traditional DBSCAN requires two predefined parameters. Suitable values of these parameters depend upon the distribution of the input point cloud. Therefore, estimating these parameters is challenging. This paper proposed a new version of DBSCAN that can automatically customize the parameters. The proposed method consists of two processes: initial parameter estimation based on grid analysis and DBSCAN based on the divide-and-conquer (DC-DBSCAN) approach, which repeatedly performs DBSCAN on each cluster separately and recursively. To verify the proposed method, we applied it to a 3D point cloud dataset that was used to analyze rockfall events at the Puiggcercos cliff, Spain. The total number of data points used in this study was 15,567. The experimental results show that the proposed method is better than the traditional DBSCAN in terms of purity and NMI scores. The purity scores of the proposed method and the traditional DBSCAN method were 96.22% and 91.09%, respectively. The NMI scores of the proposed method and the traditional DBSCAN method are 0.78 and 0.49, respectively. Also, it can detect events that traditional DBSCAN cannot detect. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: 3D point cloud; DBSCAN; Divide and conquer; Grid density; Rockfall detection
Index Keywords: Crack detection; Parameter estimation; Rock bursts; DBSCAN algorithm; Density-based spatial clustering of applications with noise; Divide and conquer; Glacier movement; Initial parameter estimation; Non-parametric; Number of datum; Spatial clustering; Clustering algorithms

Title: Dysbiosis in the salivary microbiome associated with iga nephropathy —a japanese cohort study
Affiliations: Laboratory of Applied Microbiology, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Department of Human Ecology, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Department of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery, Graduate School of Medicine, Sendai, Japan; University of Agriculture and Forestry, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Hotta Osamu Clinic, Sendai, Japan; Department of Pathology, Graduate School of Medicine, Sendai, Japan; Department of Microbiology and Infectious Diseases, Nara Medical University, Kashihara, Japan; Department of Gastroenterology, Osaka Metropolitan University Graduate School of Medicine, Osaka, Japan; Laboratory for Microbiome Sciences, RIKEN Center for Integrative Medical Sciences, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Khasnobish, Anushka, Laboratory of Applied Microbiology, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Takayasu, Lena, Department of Human Ecology, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Watanabe, Kenichi, Department of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery, Graduate School of Medicine, Sendai, Japan; Nguyen, Tien Thi Thuy, University of Agriculture and Forestry, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Arakawa, Kensuke, Laboratory of Applied Microbiology, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Hotta, Osamu, Hotta Osamu Clinic, Sendai, Japan; Joh, Kensuke, Department of Pathology, Graduate School of Medicine, Sendai, Japan; Nakano, Akiyo, Department of Microbiology and Infectious Diseases, Nara Medical University, Kashihara, Japan; Hosomi, Shuhei, Department of Gastroenterology, Osaka Metropolitan University Graduate School of Medicine, Osaka, Japan; Hattori, Masahira, Laboratory for Microbiome Sciences, RIKEN Center for Integrative Medical Sciences, Yokohama, Japan; Suda, Wataru, Laboratory for Microbiome Sciences, RIKEN Center for Integrative Medical Sciences, Yokohama, Japan; Morita, Hidetoshi, Laboratory of Applied Microbiology, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan
Abstract: IgA nephropathy is one of the leading causes of chronic kidney disease in Japan. Since the origin and mechanisms by which IgA nephropathy develops currently remain unclear, a confirmed disease diagnosis is currently only possible by highly invasive renal biopsy. With the background of the salivary microbiome as a rich source of biomarkers for systemic diseases, we herein primarily aimed to investigate the salivary microbiome as a tool for the non-invasive diagnosis of IgA nephropathy. In a comparison of salivary microbiome profiles using 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing, significant differences were observed in microbial diversity and richness between IgA nephropathy patients and healthy controls. Furthermore, recent studies reported that patients with IgA nephropathy are more likely to develop inflammatory bowel diseases and that chronic inflammation of the tonsils triggered the recurrence of IgA nephropathy. Therefore, we compared the salivary microbiome of IgA nephropathy patients with chronic tonsillitis and ulcerative colitis patients. By combining the genera selected by the random forest algorithm, we were able to distinguish IgA nephropathy from healthy controls with an area under the curve (AUC) of 0.90, from the ulcerative colitis group with AUC of 0.88, and from the chronic tonsillitis group with AUC of 0.70. Additionally, the genus Neisseria was common among the selected genera that facilitated the separation of the IgA nephropathy group from healthy controls and the chronic tonsillitis group. The present results indicate the potential of the salivary microbiome as a biomarker for the non-invasive diagnosis of IgA nephropathy. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Ikechukwu, O.M.; Dang, K.N.; Ben Abdallah, A.B.
Author full names: Ikechukwu, Ogbodo Mark (57210177190); Dang, Khanh N. (57188649063); Ben Abdallah, Abderazek (6505933787)
Title: On the Design of a Fault-Tolerant Scalable Three Dimensional NoC-Based Digital Neuromorphic System with On-Chip Learning
Affiliations: Adaptive Systems Laboratory, The University of Aizu, Aizuwakamatsu, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Ikechukwu, Ogbodo Mark, Adaptive Systems Laboratory, The University of Aizu, Aizuwakamatsu, Japan; Dang, Khanh N., Adaptive Systems Laboratory, The University of Aizu, Aizuwakamatsu, Japan, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ben Abdallah, Abderazek, Adaptive Systems Laboratory, The University of Aizu, Aizuwakamatsu, Japan
Abstract: Neuromorphic systems have shown improvements over the years, leveraging Spiking neural networks (SNN) event-driven nature to demonstrate low power consumption. As neuromorphic systems require high integration to form a functional silicon brain-like, moving to 3D integrated circuits (3D-ICs) with three-dimensional network on chip (3D-NoC) interconnect is a suitable approach that allows scalable design, shorter connections, and lower power consumption. However, highly dense neuromorphic systems also encounter the reliability issue where a single point of failure can affect the systems'operation. Because neuromorphic systems rely heavily on spike communication, an interruption or violation in the timing of spike communication can adversely affect the performance and accuracy of a neuromorphic system. This paper presents NASH,a a fault-tolerant 3D-NoC based neuromorphic system that incorporates as processing elements, lightweight spiking neuron processing cores (SNPCs) with spike-timing-dependent-plasticity (STDP) on-chip learning. Each SNPC houses 256 leaky integrate-and-fire (LIF) neurons and 65k synapses. Evaluation results on MNIST classification, using the fault-tolerant shortest-path K-means-based multicast routing algorithm (FTSP-KMCR), show that the NASH system can maintain high accuracy for up to 30% permanent fault in the interconnect with an acceptable area and power overheads when compared to other existing systems.aThis project is supported by the University of Aizu, Competitive Research Funding (CRF), Ref. UoA-P6-2020 © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Tanaka, H.; Okui, K.; Oku, Y.; Takezawa, H.; Shibutani, Y.
Author full names: Tanaka, Hiro (57200199854); Okui, Kenta (57219090050); Oku, Yuki (57219098252); Takezawa, Hironori (57219095907); Shibutani, Yoji (7006481681)
Title: Corrected power spectral density of the surface roughness of tire rubber sliding on abrasive material
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Tire Technical Center, Toyo Tire Corporation, Itami, Japan; Nanotechnology Program, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Tanaka, Hiro, Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Okui, Kenta, Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Oku, Yuki, Tire Technical Center, Toyo Tire Corporation, Itami, Japan; Takezawa, Hironori, Tire Technical Center, Toyo Tire Corporation, Itami, Japan; Shibutani, Yoji, Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Nanotechnology Program, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Various models describing the multiscale phenomena of contact mechanics and friction have been developed recently. The power spectral density (PSD) of three-dimensional (3D) surface topography is one of key elements used to formulate these mechanics models. However, the statistical variation of the PSDs of isotropic and self-affine fractal surfaces is not well understood. This paper presents a method to correct the PSD of 3D surface topography to perform statistical and spatial characterizations in a wavenumber space. To validate this data-processing methodology, we applied the areal-corrected PSD to numerical surface models and two real surface specimens made of abrasive grindstone and worn tire rubber and assessed the variation of surface roughness across scales through visual and statistical approaches. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: 3D surface topography; Power spectral density; Self-affine fractal surface; Tire rubber
Index Keywords: Abrasives; Data handling; Deformation; Power spectral density; Rubber; Spectral density; Topography; 3-D surface topography; Abrasive materials; Power spectral densities (PSD); Self-affine fractal surfaces; Spatial characterization; Statistical approach; Statistical variations; Three-dimensional (3D) surfaces; Surface roughness

Title: Public perception of biofuel usage in Vietnam
Affiliations: Graduate Program in Sustainability Science-Global Leadership Initiative (GPSS-GLI), The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Graduate School of Frontier Sciences, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Master Program in Environmental Engineering, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam

H.Q., Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Bueno, Marlet, Graduate School of Frontier Sciences, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Wang, Zhe, Graduate School of Frontier Sciences, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Nguyen, Khang Tuan, Master Program in Environmental Engineering, Viet Nam, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Ngoc Thi, Master Program in Environmental Engineering, Viet Nam, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Duong, Thuy T.M., Master Program in Environmental Engineering, Viet Nam, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dinh, Uyen Thi To, Master Program in Environmental Engineering, Viet Nam, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Sjögren, Alexander, Graduate School of Frontier Sciences, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Kim Le, Phung Thi, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thao, Nguyen Danh, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Thi An Hang, Master Program in Environmental Engineering, Viet Nam, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ikeda, Izumi, Graduate School of Frontier Sciences, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Esteban, Miguel, Graduate School of Frontier Sciences, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: This paper examines public perception of biofuels in southern Vietnam through a questionnaire survey administered to the general public in two cities in the country (Ho Chi Minh City and Phan Thiet) and experts in the field, in an attempt to understand the demand side motivations of biofuel usage. The survey enquired about the awareness of biofuel availability in Vietnam, motivations for using biofuel, and willingness to purchase biofuel. It was found that awareness was positively correlated with higher education levels, and that all groups were encouraged by the perceived environmental friendliness of biofuel. In terms of willingness to purchase, there was a clear difference in the perception of the appropriate pricing policy for biofuels between the public groups and the experts, with the former preferring higher prices and the latter lower prices. The study then concludes by discussing policy recommendations for improving consumer demand for biofuels in Vietnam and presents suggestions for future research, if the Vietnamese government decides that it is in its interest to pursue biofuels in the future. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: awareness; Biofuel; public perception; Vietnam; willingness to purchase
Index Keywords: Costs; Motivation; Sales; Surveys; awareness; Consumer demands; Environmental friendliness; Higher education; Policy recommendations; Public perception; Questionnaire surveys; Viet Nam; Biofuels

Title: Evolutionary origins of taro (Colocasia esculenta) in Southeast Asia
Affiliations: Institute of Fundamental Sciences, Massey University, Palmerston North, New Zealand; Alpha Genomics Private Limited, Islamabad, Pakistan; Biology Department De, De La Salle University, Manila, Philippines; Vegetable and Fruit Research and Development Center, Myanmar; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Ecology and Biological Resources, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Anthropology, Gauhati University, Guwahati, India; Department of Cross-Field Research, National Institutes for the Humanities National Museum of Ethnology, Suita, Japan

Abstract: As an ancient clonal root and leaf crop, taro (Colocasia esculenta, Araceae) is highly polymorphic with uncertain genetic and geographic origins. We explored chloroplast DNA diversity in cultivated and wild taros, and closely related wild taxa, and found cultivated taro to be polyphyletic, with tropical and temperate clades that appear to originate in Southeast Asia sensu lato. A third clade was found exclusively in wild populations from Southeast Asia to Australia and Papua New Guinea. Our findings do not support the hypothesis of taro domestication in Papua New Guinea, despite archaeological evidence for early use or cultivation there, and the presence of apparently natural wild populations in the region (Australia and Papua New Guinea). © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Araceae; chloroplast DNA; cultivated; domestication; evolution; wild

Authors: Binh, D.V.; KANTOUSH, S.A.; Saber, M.; Mai, N.P.; Maskey, S.; Phong, D.T.; Sumi, T.
Author full names: Binh, Doan Van (57208166301); KANTOUSH, Sameh A. (6504783297); Saber, M. (55582767500); Mai, Nguyen Phuong (57208160394); Maskey, Shreedhar (6603388008); Phong, Dang Tuan (57219412648); Sumi, Tetsuya (57890932400)
Title: Long-term alterations of flow regimes of the Mekong River and adaptation strategies for the Vietnamese Mekong Delta
Affiliations: Water Resources Research Center, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Faculty of Water Resources Engineering, Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Civil Engineering, Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; IHE Delft Institute for Water Education, Delft, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Binh, Doan Van, Water Resources Research Center, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan, Faculty of Water Resources Engineering, Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; KANTOUSH, Sameh A., Water Resources Research Center, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Saber, M., Water Resources Research Center, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Mai, Nguyen Phuong, Department of Civil Engineering, Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Maskey, Shreedhar, IHE Delft Institute for Water Education, Delft, Netherlands; Phong, Dang Tuan, Department of Civil Engineering, Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Sumi, Tetsuya, Water Resources Research Center, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan
Abstract: Study region: The Mekong basin, where climate change and anthropogenic interventions (e.g., dams, sand mining, and sluice gates) have intensified in the recent decades affecting the pristine flow regime and salinity intrusion. Study focus: This paper aims at quantifying the flow regime alterations in the entire Mekong from 1980 to 2015 and linking with the controlling drivers of alterations. In this regard, various indicators, analytical methods, and a semi two-dimensional hydrodynamic and advection-dispersion model were used. New hydrological insights for the region: The flow regime alterations in the high-dam development period (2009–2015) are more pronounced than in the low-dam development period (1993–2008), compared to the no-dam development period (1980–1992), based on most of the indicators analyzed. In the high-dam development period all existing dams with large reservoir capacity seemed to have cumulatively reduced the flood pulses and frequency and increased the low-flow discharge along the entire Mekong through reservoir operations, exceeding climate change effect. In the recent years the water levels in the low-flow season in the Vietnamese Mekong Delta (VMD) have decreased, possibly because of increased riverbed incision caused by reduced sediment supply and increased sand mining. The reduced water levels together with the increased number of the sluice gates constructed seemed to have increased salinity intrusion in the VMD which may be partly reduced by early emergency water release from upstream dams. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Discharge; Flow regimes; Hydropower dams; Salinity intrusion; The Mekong; Vietnamese Mekong Delta (VMD)

Title: Follicular Fluid Meiosis-Activating Sterol in Assisted Reproductive Techniques: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials
Affiliations: Online Research Club, Nagasaki, Japan; Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Thai Binh University of Medicine and Pharmacy, Thai Binh, Viet Nam; Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Faculty of Medicine, University of Medicine and Pharmacy at HCMC, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Faculty of Medicine, Sohag, Egypt; Università degli Studi di Sassari, Facoltà di Medicina e Chirurgia, Sassari, Italy; Zagazig University, Faculty of Medicine, Zagazig, Egypt; School of Medicine, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Department of Immunogenetics, Graduate School of Biomedical Sciences, Nagasaki, Japan; Department of Clinical Product Development, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Dang, Kien Nguyen, Online Research Club, Nagasaki, Japan, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Thai Binh University of Medicine and Pharmacy, Thai Binh, Viet Nam; Hashan, Mohammad Rashidul, Online Research Club, Nagasaki, Japan, Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Minh, Le Huu Nhat, Online Research Club, Nagasaki, Japan, Faculty of Medicine, University of Medicine and Pharmacy at HCMC, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Khalaf, Khalid Muhammad, Online Research Club, Nagasaki, Japan, Faculty of Medicine, Sohag, Egypt; Ibrahim, Hassan Yousif, Online Research Club, Nagasaki, Japan, Università degli Studi di Sassari, Facoltà di Medicina e Chirurgia, Sassari, Italy; Dessì, Alberto, Online Research Club, Nagasaki, Japan, Zagazig University, Faculty of Medicine, Zagazig, Egypt; Azzam, Mohamed Abdalla, Online Research Club, Nagasaki, Japan, School of Medicine, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Loc, Tran Thai Huu, Online Research Club, Nagasaki, Japan, Department of Immunogenetics, Graduate School of Biomedical Sciences, Nagasaki, Japan; Hirayama, Kenji, Online Research Club, Nagasaki, Japan, Department of Clinical Product Development, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan; Huy, Nguyen Tien,
Abstract: Background: Follicular fluid meiosis-activating sterol (FFMAS) is one of several molecular compounds that has been added into in vitro maturation (IVM) technique with contradictory results. Our study aimed to investigate the effects of FFMAS in assisted reproductive technology (ART). Methods: We searched systematically in PubMed, Web of Science, Scopus, Cochrane Registry of clinical trials, WHO registry of clinical trials, clinicaltrials.gov, Google Scholar until July 2017. Meta-analysis was used to investigate the efficacy and safety outcomes of FFMAS. Following the retrieval of potential articles, two independent reviewers screened and extracted included papers rigorously. Summary odds ratios (ORs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were computed for the individual outcome when data was available. Quality of included studies was assessed using Cochrane collaboration tool. Results: A total of seven randomized controlled trials involving 1198 participants with 3105 oocytes were explored in this study. Most of the studies were at low risk of bias. Our random effects model meta-analyses in maturation and abnormal embryo rate between FFMAS-exposed oocytes compared with controls revealed no significant differences (summary OR 1.00, 95% CI 0.46–2.16, p value = 0.99 and summary OR was 1.31, 95% CI 0.84–2.04, p value = 0.23, respectively). Beside, our study showed a significant increase in uniformly abnormal embryo rate in FFMAS group compared with vehicle control group (summary OR 1.98, 95% CI 1.09–3.61, p value = 0.03). No significances were noted on meta-analyses of normal embryo rate, uniformly abnormal embryo rate, uniformly normal embryo rate, mosaic embryo rate, abnormal blastomere rate, normal blastomere rate, aneuploidy mosaic embryo rate, and chaotic mosaic embryo rate. Conclusions: FFMAS showed no efficacy in maturation process in human oocytes and there was some evidence for detrimental effects in comparison to vehicle controls. We discouraged any further trials due to safety concern. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: ART; FFMAS; Infertility; IVM; Meta-analysis
Funding Texts: We\u2019re extremely grateful to Mr. Mostafa Abdo Barakat from the Faculty of Medicine, Al-Azhar University, Menoufia City, Egypt & Pratha Taiwade from Smolensk State Medical University, Smolensk City, Russia for their contribution to this study. This study was conducted in part at the Joint Usage/Research Center on Tropical Disease, Institute of Tropical Medicine, Nagasaki University.

Title: Effect of nanobubble water on anaerobic methane production from lignin
Affiliations: Faculty of Chemistry and Environment, Dalat University, Da Lat City, Lam Dong Province, Viet Nam; Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ho, Thi Hang, Faculty of Chemistry and Environment, Dalat University, Da Lat City, Lam Dong Province, Viet Nam, Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Yang, Xiaojing, Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Nie, Jingming, Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Zhao, Ziwen, Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Wei, Yu, Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Shimizu, Kazuya, Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Zhang, Zhenya, Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Lei, Zhongfang, Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: Lignocellulosic biomass is abundant in the environment, which can be used as the substrate for methane production via anaerobic digestion (AD). However, the methane production efficiency from lignocellulosic biomass is relatively low, mainly due to its refractory components, of which lignin is the major barrier to bioconversion and also resists the hydrolysis of lignocellulose, thus limiting the AD process. This study compared the effects of two different gases (N<inf>2</inf> and CO<inf>2</inf>) nanobubble water (NBW) on methane production from lignin using mono-digestion and co-digestion with acetic acid (HAc) at four different total organic carbon (TOC) ratios of HAc to lignin (97.5%:2.5%, 95%:5%, 90%:10%, and 80%:20%). Results show that N<inf>2</inf>-NBW is the promising NBW which can enhance methane production by 22% compared to the control. In addition, co-digestion of lignin with acetic acid reflects a higher methane production potential in comparison with the mono-digestion of lignin, achieving a much higher methane production (824–1061 mL CH<inf>4</inf>/g-TOC<inf>removed</inf>) when lignin content was less than 20% (TOC basis) and the highest lignin reduction (43%) at the TOC ratio of HAc to lignin of 95%:5%. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Anaerobic digestion; Lignin reduction; Methane production; Nanobubble water

Authors: Pham van, P.V.; Fujiwara, T.; Hoang, G.; Pham Phu, S.T.P.
Author full names: Pham van, Dinh (57202688379); Fujiwara, Takeshi (55502389900); Hoang, Minh Giang (57201072500); Pham Phu, Song Toan (57201079513)
Title: Comparison Between Single and Two-Stage Anaerobic Digestion of Vegetable Waste: Kinetics of Methanogenesis and Carbon Flow
Affiliations: Department of Environmental Technology and Management, Hanoi University of Civil Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Environmental Sciences, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Pham van, Dinh, Department of Environmental Technology and Management, Hanoi University of Civil Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Fujiwara, Takeshi, Department of Environmental Sciences, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Hoang, Minh Giang, Department of Environmental Technology and Management, Hanoi University of Civil Engineering, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Pham Phu, Song Toan, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Abstract: Abstract: This study aims to compare the performance and kinetics between the single-stage anaerobic digestion (SAD) and the two-stage anaerobic digestion (TAD) of vegetable waste (VW). The SAD was performed using continuously stirred tank reactors. Meanwhile, the TAD experiment was set up using a combined system involving a continuously stirred tank for hydrolysis/acidogenesis and an upflow reactor for methanogenesis. The hydrolytic reactor operated as a batch process with a retention time (RT) of 9 days, while the methane reactor was a continuous process operation with RT of 20 days. Both TAD and SAD were controlled at a temperature of 36 °C. The SAD experiments lasted for 143 days, and were characterised by the kinetic rate constant k = 0.02 day−1 which was much lower than that for the TAD (k = 0.66 − 2.16 day−1). The SAD seemed to be inhibited by high concentration of free ammonia and low inoculum to substrate ratio; herein, only 17.8–22.3% of the initial carbon could be converted into biogas (equivalent to 91–110 Nml/g-VS<inf>added</inf>) with low methane content (44.1–48.7%). Meanwhile, TAD converted 41.67% initial carbon to biogas (equivalent to 299.0–374.6 Nml/g-VS<inf>added</inf>) with high methane content (71.68–81.0%). Moreover, methanogenesis in the TAD was highly stable which enabled the digestion process to return to normal state within a few days, even though the concentrations of the influent increased to double (6.5–24.5 g-COD/l). As per these results, the TAD was much more stable, faster, and stronger than the SAD. Graphic Abstract: [Figure not available: see fulltext.] © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Low-power high-performance 32-bit RISC-V microcontroller on 65-nm silicon-on-thin-BOX (SOTB)
Affiliations: The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan; National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; University of Science and Technology, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Technology Research Association of Secure IoT Edge application based on RISC-V Open architecture (TRASIO), Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hoang, Trong Thuc, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Duran, Ckristian, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan; Nguyen, Khai Duy, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan; Dang, Tuan Kiet, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan; Quang Nhu, Quynh Nguyen, University of Science and Technology, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Than, Phuchong, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Tran, Xuan Tu, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Duc Hung, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tsukamoto, Akira, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Suzaki, Kuniyasu, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan, Technology Research Association of Secure IoT Edge application based on RISC-V Open architecture (TRASIO), Tokyo, Japan; Pham, Cong Kha, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan
Abstract: In this paper, a 32-bit RISC-V microcontroller in a 65-nm Silicon-On-Thin-BOX (SOTB) chip is presented. The system is developed based on the VexRiscv Central Processing Unit (CPU) with the Instruction Set Architecture (ISA) extensions of RV32IM. Besides the core processor, the System-on-Chip (SoC) contains 8KB of boot ROM, 64KB of on-chip memory, UART controller, SPI controller, timer, and GPIOs for LEDs and switches. The 8KB of boot ROM has 7KB of hard-code in combinational logics and 1KB of a stack in SRAM. The proposed SoC performs the Dhrystone and Coremark benchmarks with the results of 1.27 DMIPS/MHz and 2.4 Coremark/MHz, respectively. The layout occupies 1.32-mm2 of die area, which equivalents to 349,061 of NAND2 gate-counts. The 65-nm SOTB process is chosen not only because of its low-power feature but also because of the back-gate biasing technique that allows us to control the microcontroller to favor the low-power or the high-performance operations. The measurement results show that the highest operating frequency of 156-MHz is achieved at 1.2-V supply voltage (V<inf>DD</inf>) with +1.6-V back-gate bias voltage (V<inf>BB</inf>). The best power density of 33.4-µW/MHz is reached at 0.5-V V<inf>DD</inf> with +0.8-V V<inf>BB</inf>. The least current leakage of 3-nA is retrieved at 0.5-V V<inf>DD</inf> with −2.0-V V<inf>BB</inf> © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Han, Z.; Yu, T.; Phan, H.; Bui, T.Q.
Title: Extended stochastic finite element method enhanced by local mesh refinement for random voids analysis
Affiliations: Department of Engineering Mechanics, Hohai University, Nanjing, China; Institute of Theoretical and Applied Research, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Han, Zi, Department of Engineering Mechanics, Hohai University, Nanjing, China; Yu, Tiantang, Department of Engineering Mechanics, Hohai University, Nanjing, China; Phan, Haidang, Institute of Theoretical and Applied Research, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Bui, Tinh Quoc, Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: We present in this paper a novel and efficient computational approach in terms of triangular extended stochastic finite element method (T-XSFEM) for simulation of random void problems. The present T-XSFEM is further enhanced by local mesh refinement with the aid of variable-node elements to couple/link different mesh-scales, increasing the efficiency of the developed approach and saving the computational cost. The degrees of freedom are approximated with a truncated generalized polynomial chaos (GPC). The present work depends on the extension of extended finite element method (XFEM) to the stochastic context, containing implicit expression of voids through the random level set functions. A new partition technique is defined to divide the random domain for integration by using a priori knowledge of the void shape function, which can further reduce the computational time. To show the effectiveness and accuracy of the developed approach, numerical experiments are studied and computed results are compared with existing reference solutions. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Binh, Doan Van (57208166301); Wietlisbach, Basil (57208239621); KANTOUSH, Sameh A. (6504783297); Ho, Loc Huu (57189027363); Park, Edward (56088790300); De Cesare, Giovanni (56252916200); Cuong, Do Huy (55355420400); Tung, Nguyenxuan (57193698929); Sumi, Tetsuya (57890932400)
Title: A novel method for river bank detection from landsat satellite data: A case study in the Vietnamese Mekong delta
Affiliations: Water Resources Research Center, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Faculty of Water Resources Engineering, Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Staubli, Kurath & Partner AG, Zurich, Switzerland; National Institute of Education, Singapore City, Singapore; Asian School of the Environment, Singapore City, Singapore; Hydraulic Platform LCH, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland; Institute of Marine Geology and Geophysics, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Binh, Doan Van, Water Resources Research Center, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan, Faculty of Water Resources Engineering, Thuyloi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Wietlisbach, Basil, Staubli, Kurath & Partner AG, Zurich, Switzerland; KANTOUSH, Sameh A., Water Resources Research Center, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Ho, Loc Huu, National Institute of Education, Singapore City, Singapore; Park, Edward, National Institute of Education, Singapore City, Singapore, Asian School of the Environment, Singapore City, Singapore; De Cesare, Giovanni, Hydraulic Platform LCH, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland; Cuong, Do Huy, Institute of Marine Geology and Geophysics, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tung, Nguyenxuan, Institute of Marine Geology and Geophysics, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Sumi, Tetsuya, Water Resources Research Center, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan
Abstract: River bank (RB) erosion is a global issue affecting livelihoods and properties of millions of people. However, it has not received enough attention in the Vietnamese Mekong Delta (VMD), i.e., the world’s third largest delta, compared to salinity intrusion and flooding. There have been several studies examining RB and coastal erosion in the VMD using remotely sensed satellite data, but the applied methodology was not adequately validated. Therefore, we developed a novel SRBED (Spectral RB Erosion Detection) method, in which the M-AMERL (Modified Automated Method for Extracting Rivers and Lakes) is proposed, and a new RB change detection algorithm using Landsat data. The results show that NDWI (Normalized Difference Water Index) and MNDWI (Modified Normalized Difference Water Index) using the M-AMERL algorithm (i.e., NDWI<inf>M-AMERL</inf>, MNDWI<inf>M-AMERL</inf>) perform better than other indices. Furthermore, the NDWI<inf>M-AMERL; SMA</inf> (i.e., NDWI<inf>M-AMERL</inf> using the SMA (Spectral Mixture Analysis) algorithm) is the best RB extraction method in the VMD. The NDWI<inf>M-AMERL; SMA</inf> performs better than the MNDWI, NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index), and WNDWI (Weighted Normalized Difference Water Index) indices by 35–41%, 70% and 30%, respectively. Moreover, the NDVI index is not recommended for assessing RB changes in the delta. Applying the developed SRBED method and RB change detection algorithm, we estimated a net erosion area of the RB of –1.5 km2 from 2008 to 2014 in the Tien River from Tan Chau to My Thuan, with a mean erosion width of –2.64 m and maximum erosion widths exceeding 60 m in places. Our advanced method can be applied in other river deltas having similar characteristics, and the results from our study are helpful in future studies in the VMD. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: A survey of barley pip aquaporin ionic conductance reveals ca2+-sensitive hvpip2;8 na+ and k+ conductance
Affiliations: Institute of Plant Science and Resources, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Faculty of Agronomy, University of Agriculture and Forestry, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Division of Applied Biology, Shinshu University, Matsumoto, Japan; The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia; ANU Research School of Biology, Canberra, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Sen Thi Huong, Institute of Plant Science and Resources, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan, Faculty of Agronomy, University of Agriculture and Forestry, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Imran, Shahin, Institute of Plant Science and Resources, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Horie, Tomoaki, Division of Applied Biology, Shinshu University, Matsumoto, Japan; Qiu, Jiaen, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia; McGaughey, Samantha A., ANU Research School of Biology, Canberra, Australia; Byrt, Caitlin Siobhan, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia, ANU Research School of Biology, Canberra, Australia; Tyerman, Stephen Donald, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia; Katsuhara, Maki, Institute of Plant Science and Resources, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan
Abstract: Some plasma membrane intrinsic protein (PIP) aquaporins can facilitate ion transport. Here we report that one of the 12 barley PIPs (PIP1 and PIP2) tested, HvPIP2;8, facilitated cation transport when expressed in Xenopus laevis oocytes. HvPIP2;8-associated ion currents were detected with Na+ and K+, but not Cs+, Rb+, or Li+, and was inhibited by Ba2+, Ca2+, and Cd2+ and to a lesser extent Mg2+, which also interacted with Ca2+. Currents were reduced in the presence of K+, Cs+, Rb+, or Li+ relative to Na+ alone. Five HvPIP1 isoforms co-expressed with HvPIP2;8 inhibited the ion conductance relative to HvPIP2;8 alone but HvPIP1;3 and HvPIP1;4 with HvPIP2;8 maintained the ion conductance at a lower level. HvPIP2;8 water permeability was similar to that of a C-terminal phosphorylation mimic mutant HvPIP2;8 S285D, but HvPIP2;8 S285D showed a negative linear correlation between water permeability and ion conductance that was modified by a kinase inhibitor treatment. HvPIP2;8 transcript abundance increased in barley shoot tissues following salt treatments in a salt-tolerant cultivar Haruna-Nijo, but not in salt-sensitive I743. There is potential for HvPIP2;8 to be involved in barley salt-stress responses, and HvPIP2;8 could facilitate both water and Na+/K+ transport activity, depending on the phosphorylation status. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Luu, V.N.; Murakami, K.; Samouh, H.; Maruyama, I.; Suzuki, K.; Prak Tom, P.; Chen, L.; Kano, S.; Yang, H.; Abe, H.; Suzuki, M.
Author full names: Luu, Vu Nhut (57217391798); Murakami, Kenta (55961434500); Samouh, Hamza (56926616200); Maruyama, Ippei (7101915385); Suzuki, Kiyoteru (57217389074); Prak Tom, Phongsakorn (56342425800); Chen, Liang (57188700759); Kano, Sho (56080858800); Yang, Huilong (56505737500); Abe, Hiroaki (7404482014); Suzuki, Masahide (7408133850)
Title: Swelling of alpha-quartz induced by MeV ions irradiation: Critical dose and swelling mechanism
Affiliations: Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Center for Non-Destructive Evaluation, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; Mitsubishi Research Institute, Inc., Chiyoda-Ku, Japan; The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Luu, Vu Nhut, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan, Center for Non-Destructive Evaluation, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Murakami, Kenta, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Samouh, Hamza, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; Maruyama, Ippei, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; Suzuki, Kiyoteru, Mitsubishi Research Institute, Inc., Chiyoda-Ku, Japan; Prak Tom, Phongsakorn, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Chen, Liang, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Kano, Sho, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Yang, Huilong, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Abe, Hiroaki, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Suzuki, Masahide, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan
Abstract: Alpha-SiO<inf>2</inf>, as one of the main minerals existing in almost all rock-forming aggregates in structural concrete, can undergo undesirable volume expansion up to 17.8% under irradiation, which in turn can lead to cracking or de-bonding between aggregates and mortar matrix. To better understand the expansion behavior, crystal SiO<inf>2</inf> was irradiated by 2 MeV He and 3 MeV Si ions at 44 °C, 92 °C and 142 °C, following step height measurement to quantify the volume change. The amorphization was confirmed by transmission electron microscopy. We found that even after the amorphization has fully occurred, the volume expansion continued at higher dose, and irradiation temperature enhanced the expansion rate. To describe the volume change in amorphized SiO<inf>2</inf>, we have developed an empirical model based on the Poisson law, considering the contribution of collision and ionization process, and estimated that the critical dose for swelling in alpha-SiO<inf>2</inf> was about 0.11 dpa (displacements per atom). The viscous flow effect, whose activation energy has been estimated as 0.13 eV in our study, could play an important role in swelling especially after the amorphization, which can explain the slower swelling process induced by neutron irradiation. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Amorphization; Concrete degradation; Irradiation defects; Stress relaxation
Index Keywords: Activation energy; Aggregates; Amorphization; Concrete aggregates; High resolution transmission electron microscopy; Silica; Silicon; Swelling; Displacements per atoms; Expansion behavior; Ionization process; Irradiation temperature; Step height measurement; Structural concretes; Swelling mechanism; Volume expansion; Neutron irradiation

Authors: Dong, D.D.; Moritaka, M.; Liu, R.; Fukuda, S.
Author full names: Dong, Dzung Dao (57217214300); Moritaka, Masahiro (53863887400); Liu, Ran (57194557458); Fukuda, Susiuno (9232596300)
Title: Restructuring toward a modernized agro-food value chain through vertical integration and contract farming: the swine-to-pork industry in Vietnam
Source title: Journal of Agribusiness in Developing and Emerging Economies
Affiliations: Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Faculty of Accounting and Business Management, Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Dong, Dzung Dao, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan, Faculty of Accounting and Business Management, Vietnam National University of Agriculture, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Moritaka, Masahiro, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Liu, Ran, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Fukuda, Susiuno, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: Purpose: Restructuring swine and pork value chain plays important role in agriculture reformation of Vietnam, the top global pork-lover and swine producer worldwide. This study aims at investigating the modernization of its entire swine-to-pork value chain. Design/methodology/approach: This study combines the secondary data and primary data. The secondary data included the publications, procurements, databases from both worldwide and in Vietnam. Primary data comprised the results from field-trips in March 2018 and February 2019 that used in-depth interviews with representative key persons of involving stake-holders. Findings: The prevalence of contract farming, vertical expansion and conglomerate mergers mainly boost vertical coordination in the industry, which creates three hierarchy paradigms of governance named the full- and semi-vertically integrated model, and the formal coordinating relation institution. Consequently, consolidation has occurred and lead the swine and pork value chain toward modernization. Research limitations/implications: This study generalizes its first trends of the modernization of the swine-to-pork industry instead of provides its concreted impacts to the involved stakeholders. Social implications: Swine and pork industries retain historical and socio-political issues in Vietnam. Social problems are going to raise if number of traditional swine producers are failed in the competition from the equipped large-scale producers leading by the giant vertically-integrated contractors. Originality/value: This study provides the empirical synthesis of the vertical coordination in entitle swine and pork value chain of Vietnam through combining the view of the strategic alliance of the firm and global value chain governance. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Consolidation; Contract farming; Coordination; Pig; Pork; Value chain; Vertical integration; Vietnam

Authors: Hoang, T.T.; Truong, V.T.; Hayashi, M.; Tadono, T.; Nasahara, K.N.
Author full names: Hoang, Thanh Tung (59854753600); Truong, Van Thinh (57211500444); Hayashi, Masato (57200597357); Tadono, Takeo (6602942477); Nasahara, Kenlo Nishida (24178270500)
Title: New JAXA high-resolution land use/land cover map for Vietnam aiming for natural forest and plantation forest monitoring
Affiliations: Vietnam Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology and Climate Change, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Earth Observation Research Center, Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency, Chofu, Japan; Faculty of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hoang, Thanh Tung, Vietnam Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology and Climate Change, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Truong, Van Thinh, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hayashi, Masato, Earth Observation Research Center, Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency, Chofu, Japan; Tadono, Takeo, Earth Observation Research Center, Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency, Chofu, Japan; Nasahara, Kenlo Nishida, Faculty of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: Highly detailed and accurate forest maps are important for various applications including forest monitoring, forestry policy, climate change, and biodiversity loss. This study demonstrates a comprehensive and geographically transferable approach to produce a 12 category high-resolution land use/land cover (LULC) map over mainland Vietnam in 2016 by remote sensing data. The map included several natural forest categories (evergreen broadleaf, deciduous (mostly deciduous broadleaf), and coniferous (mostly evergreen coniferous)) and one category representing all popular plantation forests in Vietnam such as acacia (Acacia mangium, Acacia auriculiformis, Acacia hybrid), eucalyptus (Eucalyptus globulus), rubber (Hevea brasiliensis), and others. The approach combined the advantages of various sensor data by integrating their posterior probabilities resulting from applying a probabilistic classifier (comprised of kernel density estimation and Bayesian inference) to each datum individually. By using different synthetic aperture radar (SAR) images (PALSAR-2/ScanSAR, PALSAR-2 mosaic, Sentinel-1), optical images (Sentinel-2, Landsat-8) and topography data (AW3D30), the resultant map achieved 85.6% for the overall accuracy. The major forest classes including evergreen broadleaf forests and plantation forests had a user's accuracy and producer's accuracy ranging from 86.0% to 95.3%. Our map identified 9.55 × 106 ha (±0.16 × 106 ha) of natural forests and 3.89 × 106 ha (±0.11 × 106 ha) of plantation forests over mainland Vietnam, which were close to the Vietnamese government's statistics (with differences of less than 8%). This study's result provides a reliable input/reference to support forestry policy and land sciences in Vietnam. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Dien, L.X.; Luu, Q.-T.; Nguyen, T.-T.; Huynh, D.-C.; Quan, D.-Q.; Yoshimura, M.; Ishida, T.
Author full names: Dien, Luong Xuan (56596628200); Luu, Quynh Trang (57216186558); Nguyen, Tien Thanh (59603604700); Huynh, Chinh Dang (16067226200); Quan, Ngoduc (56033358000); Yoshimura, Mashamichi (7403136411); Ishida, Tamao (55463415000)
Title: Facile Synthesis of MnO2@SiO2/Carbon Nanocomposite-based Gold Catalysts from Rice Husk for Low-Temperature CO Oxidation
Affiliations: School of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Toyota Technological Institute, Nagoya, Japan; Research Center for Gold Chemistry, Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hachioji, Japan; School of Engineering Physics, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Dien, Luong Xuan, School of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Research Center for Gold Chemistry, Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hachioji, Japan; Luu, Quynh Trang, School of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Tien Thanh, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Huynh, Chinh Dang, School of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Quan, Ngoduc, School of Engineering Physics, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yoshimura, Mashamichi, Toyota Technological Institute, Nagoya, Japan; Ishida, Tamao, Research Center for Gold Chemistry, Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hachioji, Japan
Abstract: Herein, MnO<inf>2</inf>@SiO<inf>2</inf>/C was produced from rice husk derived SiO<inf>2</inf>/carbon composite and MnO<inf>2</inf> via hydrothermal method. The nanostructure gave good microstructural, morphological properties with highly catalytic properties. The hybrid catalyst comprising of MnO<inf>2</inf>@SiO<inf>2</inf>/C nanocomposite-supported gold nanoparticles was successfully fabricated by the novel solid grinding and tested for CO oxidation’s application. MnO<inf>2</inf> nanoballs are 5 − 8 nm in diameter with a shell thickness of 1 nm, packing with laminar [MnO<inf>6</inf>] unit cells. The as-prepared gold catalysts containing 2wt% of Au loading, exhibited 50% CO conversion and a high specific activity of 0.21 mol<inf>CO</inf> g<inf>Au</inf>−1 h−1 at 38 °C. Graphic Abstract: MnO2@SiO2/C nanocomposite-supported gold nanoparticles were prepared by solid grinding using a non-volatile organogold(III) complex and rice husk. The catalysts showed high activity for CO oxidation. [Figure not available: see fulltext.]. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Islam, M.S.; van Nguyen, T.; Sakamoto, W.; Takagi, S.
Author full names: Islam, Md Sayeedul (55323699000); van Nguyen, Toan (57215611610); Sakamoto, Wataru (55641854100); Takagi, Shingo (7401494618)
Title: Phototropin- and photosynthesis-dependent mitochondrial positioning in Arabidopsis thaliana mesophyll cells
Affiliations: Department of Biological Sciences, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; Agricultural Genetics Institute, National Key Laboratory for Plant Cell Biotechnology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Institute of Plant Science and Resources, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Islam, Md Sayeedul, Department of Biological Sciences, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan; van Nguyen, Toan, Department of Biological Sciences, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan, Agricultural Genetics Institute, National Key Laboratory for Plant Cell Biotechnology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Sakamoto, Wataru, Institute of Plant Science and Resources, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Takagi, Shingo, Department of Biological Sciences, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: Mitochondria are frequently observed in the vicinity of chloroplasts in photosynthesizing cells, and this association is considered necessary for their metabolic interactions. We previously reported that, in leaf palisade cells of Arabidopsis thaliana, mitochondria exhibit blue-light-dependent redistribution together with chloroplasts, which conduct accumulation and avoidance responses under the control of blue-light receptor phototropins. In this study, precise motility analyses by fluorescent microscopy revealed that the individual mitochondria in palisade cells, labeled with green fluorescent protein, exhibit typical stop-and-go movement. When exposed to blue light, the velocity of moving mitochondria increased in 30 min, whereas after 4 h, the frequency of stoppage of mitochondrial movement markedly increased. Using different mutant plants, we concluded that the presence of both phototropin1 and phototropin2 is necessary for the early acceleration of mitochondrial movement. On the contrary, the late enhancement of stoppage of mitochondrial movement occurs only in the presence of phototropin2 and only when intact photosynthesis takes place. A plasma-membrane ghost assay suggested that the stopped mitochondria are firmly adhered to chloroplasts. These results indicate that the physical interaction between mitochondria and chloroplasts is cooperatively mediated by phototropin2- and photosynthesis-dependent signals. The present study might add novel regulatory mechanism for light-dependent plant organelle interactions. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Reaction probability and kinetics of water splitting on the penta-NiAs2monolayer from an: Ab initio molecular dynamics investigation
Affiliations: Division of Computational Physics, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Faculty of Applied Sciences, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Future Materials & Devices Lab., Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Faculty of Natural Sciences, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Department of Chemistry, Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Department of Physics and Nanotechnology, SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, India; School of Physics, Suranaree University of Technology, Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Ho, Thi H., Division of Computational Physics, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Faculty of Applied Sciences, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Dong, Hieucao, Future Materials & Devices Lab., Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam, Faculty of Natural Sciences, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Bui, Viet Quoc, Department of Chemistry, Sungkyunkwan University, Seoul, South Korea; Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan, Department of Physics and Nanotechnology, SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, India, School of Physics, Suranaree University of Technology, Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; Le, Hungminh, Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Abstract: The reaction probability and kinetics of the water splitting process on the penta-NiAs2 monolayer are studied using ab initio molecular dynamics simulations. A total of 100 trajectories are investigated, in which a H2O molecule is set to strike the surface with a translational energy of 1 eV or 2 eV. The results show that the NiAs2 monolayer is an excellent candidate for the activation of water splitting with a reaction probability of 94% for both energy levels. Interestingly, the kinetics of two O-H dissociation stages varies greatly with respect to the inletting translational energy. Interpreting the reaction data for the 1 eV case, we conclude that O-H1 and O-H2 dissociations are first-order processes. However, such dissociation steps become pseudo-zeroth order in the 2 eV case. At the time of the dissociation, the force acting on atoms and the principal component analysis suggest that the two OH breaking stages behave like harmonic springs until reaching the dissociation. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Arsenic compounds; Dissociation; Kinetics; Molecular dynamics; Monolayers; Nickel compounds; Probability; Ab initio molecular dynamics; Ab initio molecular dynamics simulation; First-order process; H2O molecules; Harmonic springs; Reaction probability; Translational energy; Water splitting; Reaction kinetics
